generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, is of great interest in the field of water physics. However, the structure of ice II with guest molecules is still unknown. In this work, we report the structure of ice II with neon atoms as the guest molecules. The guest Ne atoms occupy the centers of D2O channels and have substantial freedom of movement owing to the lack of direct bonding between guest molecules and host lattices. The structure is thermodynamically stable at 480 MPa and 260 K. The structure of ice II with guest molecules is expected to be of great importance in the field of water physics.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of current debate. A common theme is the need to provide a categorical foundation for the mathematical apparatus of quantum mechanics. In this paper, we provide such a foundation. Our approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators on the category of sets. This resolves a question raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. To understand the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content that is characteristic of the Myxozoa, we compared the genomes of two myxozoans to the genome of a cnidarian parasite and to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian host. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals, and that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements required for survival as parasites. Our findings suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This reduction in genome size and gene content may have been a necessary step in the evolution of the Myxozoa.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to impair nuclear import of importin/karyopherin, thereby blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 and impairing the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be exploited by SARS-CoV-2 to survive the host immune response. Our study also provides a potential target for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. In this study, we show that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries as the Earth’s climate warms. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in these countries. The instability of global grain trade and international grain prices will increase, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. Our results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify the diet breadth, composition, and overlap of seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree of species overlap in diet was correlated with the degree of species overlap in proportional grass consumption, but that the grass consumption of each species was different from that of all others. These results suggest that the degree of species overlap in diet may be a more accurate measure of competition than the degree of species overlap in proportional grass consumption. Our results also suggest that the diversity of large mammal species may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the brink of closure. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months. These findings suggest that the government should provide grants rather than loans to small businesses, as the former are less likely to be used for nonessential expenses and are less likely to lead to layoffs.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink is of fundamental importance to understand the fate of the missing plastic debris.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is thought to have formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. However, the formation of the solar system is not a closed system, and the solar system is continuously exposed to the interstellar medium. We determined the age of 40 large silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is much older than the age of the solar system. The grains are likely parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium, and the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium. The grains are likely exposed to the interstellar medium for a long time, and the solar system is continuously exposed to the interstellar medium. This work provides a new perspective on the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is a defining feature of animal domestication. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, in which a female cares for her offspring by sharing her own food, is the most effective way to increase the reproductive output of a species. We find that the practice of allonursing is associated with larger litters, which in turn are associated with larger offspring. This result suggests that the ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is the most important factor limiting the reproductive output of placental mammals. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of domestication and the evolution of the placenta. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is the main form of α-syn that is neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would slow down the neurodegenerative process and would improve the quality of life of MSA patients.

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines the interior of blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling blood pressure, and controlling the clotting process. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of short-range connections. The network is designed to be both efficient and robust in the transmission of information.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated unprecedented data challenges. In response, we have developed a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals and auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are expected to be useful for a wide range of applications, including epidemiological modeling, public health surveillance, and research. The data are also expected to be useful for understanding and tracking the pandemic in the United States and elsewhere.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is constantly changing in response to the host’s environment and diet. The role of the microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the host. In this study, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome of herbivores, synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the microbiome. This study provides a foundation for the discovery of natural products from anaerobic fungi and the development of new strategies for the control of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings have important implications for understanding the role of anxiety in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design of a single material phase to realize a specific response is limited by the material properties and the design space is restricted. Here, we propose a synthesis method to design composite structures that are composed of multiple material phases to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized and manufactured with different elastomers with distinct behaviors. The structures seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work can inspire the design of mechanical structures with desired responses and the development of new manufacturing methods.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in the erythroid lineage. We show that IGF2BP1 is developmentally silenced in the adult erythroid system and that overexpression of IGF2BP1 in erythroid cells causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This change is mediated by reduced expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important in the development of hemoglobin disorders and in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in aging. (Show more)

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and monounsaturated fatty acid production, and can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway or by inducing ferroptosis. These findings provide a rationale for the combination of ferroptosis induction with PI3K-AKT pathway inhibition in cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) is the major treatment for hypertension. However, the mechanisms of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and vascular remodeling are not well understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI proteins, which are up-regulated in hypertensive rats. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings provide a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our data also suggest that LCCBs may be a potential target for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older forest bird populations. We also show that the NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented here can be applied to other antibiotic classes. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, and that can be trained and applied with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many image-processing problems. The code is available at this https URL .

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices, especially those emitting light, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that such devices can have a negative impact on sleep, with implications for health and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 11.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the stage of life at which it is deleted.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles and their plant-feeding habits is the result of multiple factors, including the codiversification of beetles and plants, and the evolution of genes that enabled the digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work has the potential to accelerate the development of antibody-based therapeutics for COVID-19.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and anthropologists. We conducted a large-scale experiment in which participants learned from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. We found that larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This study also highlights the importance of the working memory in the process of cultural transmission. Our results suggest that the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). This study also highlights the importance of the working memory in the process of cultural transmission.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE genotype. APOE isoform is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that the amount of C1q protein accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles: C1q accumulation was significantly reduced in APOE2 knock-in (KI) animals and was significantly increased in APOE4 KI animals compared with APOE3 KI animals. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is likely to have formed by two-step nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase. This two-step nucleation scenario provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is the only known cognitive skill that evolved in humans but not elsewhere. This suggests that language is a uniquely important part of the human mind. Here we show that a class of deep learning models, which are trained to predict the next word in a sentence, are able to explain nearly all of the neural variance associated with processing of sentences in the human brain. This suggests that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are fundamentally computational “transformers” that can be understood in terms of deep learning. These results provide computational evidence for the importance of language in the human mind.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear why DL works, and why it is so effective. In this paper, we show that the instability of DL is closely related to the lack of theoretical understanding of the relationship between the structure of the algorithm and the stability of the solution. We prove that, for some well-posed problems, there exist algorithms that can compute stable solutions, and we prove that there do not exist such algorithms for other problems. This provides a classification theory of the relationship between the structure of the algorithm and the stability of the solution. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the development of DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past pandemics. This paper shows that the failure to learn from past pandemics is, in fact, a failure to learn from past psychological experiments.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The cause of the difference between the two bacteria is unknown. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria have retained many of the same genes, despite having diverged from a common ancestor 13.9 Mya. This suggests that the two bacteria have retained the same core functions for thousands of years. This knowledge may help us to understand the cause of the difference between the two bacteria and the cause of the difference between leprosy and other diseases caused by bacteria. (Show more)

The evolution of entanglement is a key question in quantum mechanics. It is also a fundamental problem in statistical mechanics, as it is the origin of the thermodynamic entropy. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most challenging regime for the exact computation of the entanglement. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. This work opens the way to the exact computation of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has affected millions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is being developed by recoding the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs. This vaccine candidate is expected to be safe, effective, and scalable.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been a human ectoparasite vector. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector and used Bayesian inference to test the model against historical mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our model can be used to study the historical spread of plague in Europe. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the brain is the most fundamental process in the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain size as a proxy for the evolution of brain power is not without problems. We show that, by using the number of neurons, we can get a more accurate picture of the evolution of brain power.

The mitochondrial chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the role of TRAP1 in normal cells is less clear. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell death. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments is still poorly understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, and that this process is enhanced by a mechanical torque. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF/cofilin in severing highly connected filament networks, which is critical for many cellular processes. Our findings also suggest that this mechanochemical mechanism could be used to design new materials with tunable mechanical properties.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent history of admixture. The history of Madagascar is complex, and our results show that the island is a unique case study for understanding the history of human migrations.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence our own. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and the role of social media in this process.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into protein sequences. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome encounters. There is a growing appreciation that mRNA sequences can also be posttranscriptionally modified, and that these modifications can have important effects on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the presence of one of the most common mRNA modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have important consequences for protein synthesis, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences in vivo. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in gene expression and disease. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common disease in the world, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of this disease. The mechanisms that allow rhinovirus to replicate preferentially at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity are not well understood. Here, we show that the mouse common cold virus, mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature of the mouse. We also show that the mouse common cold virus exploits the innate immune response to rhinovirus to preferentially replicate at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the surface-attached Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense the environment and regulate its virulence. This is achieved by a mechanochemical mechanism where the pili are directly involved in the sensing process. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of pili in bacterial surface attachment and virulence, and also for developing new strategies to combat bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the concentrations of these chemicals are often above the legal limits. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide problem and the first global assessment of the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global problem and that the consequences for biodiversity are likely to be severe.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been detected in a variety of animal species, including deer. However, the role of wildlife in the ongoing pandemic is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, and the discovery of multiple human lineages in deer. Our findings suggest that the virus has been circulating in deer for some time, and that the virus has the potential to spread between deer and humans. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world has been building dams since the 1920s, but the practice stopped in the 1970s. This paper shows that the reasons for this are the same as today: the best sites for dams were already developed, and environmental and social concerns made the costs unacceptable. The paper also shows that the same problems are being repeated: disrupting river ecology, deforestation, losing aquatic and terrestrial biodiversity, releasing substantial greenhouse gases, displacing thousands of people, and altering people’s livelihoods plus affecting the food systems, water quality, and agriculture near them. The paper also shows that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. Finally, the paper proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is thought to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which form toxic deposits in the brain. However, we show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is the primary cause of an early inflammatory response, which may be a key factor in the development of AD.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most enigmatic. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken is from the Near East, but the history of the domestic chicken in the Near East is still largely unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the earliest sites in the Southern Levant, which show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and that the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens dates to the Hellenistic period. This is a crucial step in the history of the chicken, as it shows that the chicken was not only a symbolic animal in the Near East, but also a source of economic benefits. This is an important step in the history of the chicken, which is still largely unknown. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not known how many distinct intermediates are formed. This work shows that the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein, proceeds through at least two distinct intermediates. The results suggest that the folding of a protein can proceed through more than one intermediate, and that the number of intermediates formed can be a function of the size of the protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the levels of this class of molecules remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to be the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, is the primary enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in Escherichia coli. We also show that RppH prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts, and that the unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. These findings have implications for understanding the role of RppH-catalyzed decapping in the regulation of gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the underlying mechanisms are complex and not fully understood. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is involved in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, can restore the function of T cells and decrease the expansion of immunosuppressive cells, such as Tregs and MDSCs, in sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic target for sepsis. This study also provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the dynamics of the biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be tuned to a critical state, where it self-adjusts to changes in the environment. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a general method to explore the phase diagram of diamond. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

The discovery of the first antifungal peptide, defensin, in plants has led to the development of a new class of plant-derived antifungal compounds. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new antifungal peptide, NCR044, from Medicago truncatula. We show that this peptide is highly diverse in sequence and is expressed in nodules of the model legume. We also show that this peptide is highly effective against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and Fusarium spp. It binds to phosphoinositides and induces reactive oxygen species, followed by cell death. This work provides a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This would be a significant contribution to the control of plant fungal diseases. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the contributions of each sex are critical to reproductive success. However, the extent of intersexual continuity is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of mutations in VWF, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the single molecule data are representative of the bulk phase. These results provide a mechanism for the effects of force on VWF binding to platelets. They also provide a method for measuring the effects of mutations in VWF. This method can be used to study other proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been shown to influence health and disease. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, and the number of studies is still small compared to the number of bacteria. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and we show that viruses are associated with many diseases. This resource will enable future studies to investigate the role of viruses in health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This technique can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this technique by analyzing a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature history of the early Earth is a central issue in the study of the origin and early evolution of life. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is in broad agreement with the hypothesis that the surface temperature of the early Earth decreased over time. However, the isotopic record may be subject to uncertainties, and the temperature inferred from the isotopic record may not reflect the temperature of the surface environment. We here present evidence that the temperature of the surface environment of the early Earth decreased over time, consistent with the hypothesis that the surface temperature of the early Earth decreased over time.

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They are opened and closed by their pore gates, which are composed of multiple domains. The activation gate of K+ channels is located at the intracellular end of the pore and is commonly associated with slow C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel, which is normally open and has no classic activation gate, has a slow C-type inactivation that is closed state-dependent and that its rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the relationship between channel activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. It also provides a possible mechanism for the BK channel’s normal closing. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the most important steps in the parasite’s life cycle is invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), where it replicates and causes disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, and this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the cell. This change in the cell’s properties, in turn, reduces the energy barrier to invasion, allowing the parasite to overcome this barrier and invade the cell. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process, suggesting that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical force, but rather a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This finding could lead to the development of new strategies to combat malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a general approach to understand the relationship between strain and electronic properties of solids. This work is expected to be of interest to the general physics community.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. We show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza epidemiology and pathogenesis. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build a tree-like syntactic structure of a sentence word by word, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probability, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. The merge operation is a fundamental operation in natural language processing and is likely to be important in other domains of artificial intelligence.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of redundant genes and their roles in the body. It also provides a platform for future studies on the regulation of redundant genes.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the locus coeruleus. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in the normal regulation of feeding.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is a critical component of sustainable agriculture. In this work, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the nitrogen-fixing bacteria are only active when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for controlling the activity of diazotrophs in association with plants. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species.
