The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. The causes of this deforestation are complex and include the actions of local communities. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce the rate of deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced the rate of deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects of the program are imprecise because of the difficulty of measuring the effects of the program. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused billions of dollars in economic losses. The development of vaccines is a critical tool in the fight against the pandemic. In this study, we report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-established as a target for vaccine development. The variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be expressed on a virus-like particle, which reduces the weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a potential tool for the development of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of cancer. In this study, we show that the zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the zebrafish ALK/Ltk receptor pair, which in turn, is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humanity. The emergence of plague from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a story of rapid evolution and dispersal, and the study of ancient genomes has allowed us to explore this process in unprecedented detail. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which reveal a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide a unique perspective on the formative years of plague, and the study of ancient genomes will continue to provide new insights into the history of this devastating pathogen. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also have implications for understanding the 2020 American presidential election.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 1.1 billion ha of natural grassland worldwide. This has resulted in the release of 1,500 Pg C to the atmosphere, which is equivalent to the total C stored in the world’s forests. In this study, we show that the restoration of grasslands and the integration of livestock into annual cropping systems can sequester carbon in the soil. This is a significant contribution to the global carbon cycle and a key step in the transition to climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We developed a risk assessment framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a more informed and effective response to future viral threats.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this trait are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the chemical biology of Campanulaceae. (Show more)

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the history of the European population during the period between the migrations of peoples and the expansion of the Roman Empire is poorly understood. Here we present a case study of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations and who were buried with jewelry. Our analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests that they had a genetic background that was not typical for the population of the time. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly discovered pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future bat-to-human spillover events. (Show more

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the regional pathogen landscape and emerging pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. We show that vector-borne pathogens are the most common clinical category, and that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, are also detected. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Our study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, and the potential for rapid public health response. Ongoing pathogen surveillance is needed to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study is a proof of concept for the use of metagenomic sequencing in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by the pol δ/PCNA holoenzyme, which is responsible for the synthesis of the Okazaki fragment. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable on undamaged DNA and that it dissociates rapidly from PCNA on encountering a DNA lesion. These results have profound implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate and convert RNA templates into functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the goal of creating a functional RNA world in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic well-being of the residents of those neighborhoods.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, was given to the patients, and the results showed that it could reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe or critical COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. We report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. We also demonstrate that xanthocillin-derived isocyanide metabolites have antimicrobial properties and that these properties are dependent on copper. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the impact of metal homeostasis on fungal interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The formation of silica in the martian interior is a key to understanding the evolution of the planet. The chemistry and mineralogy of silica in the martian interior is not well known. We report the detection of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars. The tridymitic mudstone has cogenetic detrital feldspar, magnetite, and any residual high-SiO2 glass, and is possibly sourced from the crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous silica is precipitated from multiple aqueous solutions, possibly with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The chemistry and mineralogy of silica in the martian interior will help us understand the evolution of the planet. (Less)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s largest terrestrial carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the productivity of forests in Europe and Asia. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that these cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We have developed a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapeutics. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the rapid testing of potential therapeutics.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the tick microbiota to enhance transmission are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. We also show that antifreeze glycoprotein alters the structure of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical barrier for Anaplasma colonization. Finally, we show that antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of gut bacteria, which alters the permeability of the gut barrier and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in vertebrate evolution. The discovery of a new group of early pygostylians provides new insights into the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the coupling between the different components of the system. In this paper, we show that the coupling between the troposphere and the stratosphere is important for the climate system, and that the coupling is stronger than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and the evolution of color is a major topic in biology. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color is determined by a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is normally present in red colors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our findings also provide a molecular basis for the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to survive in hypoxic regions of the tumor microenvironment is a key feature of the disease. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is required for the development of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for the initiation of the disease. Thus, ALKBH5 is a key regulator of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for the initiation of the disease. Our findings have implications for the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. The intestinal epithelium is constantly exposed to environmental stimuli, which can lead to the activation of the immune system and the development of inflammatory diseases. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. Our study provides a potential mechanism for the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and a target for the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human receptor, ACE2, and the cellular protease, TMPRSS2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has resulted in a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain, which may facilitate virus entry. Our results provide a structural basis for the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 83.18 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements.

Fire is a key natural disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in climate change is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, have been the dominant driver of global fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has the potential to reduce warming. However, this effect is uncertain because of the large uncertainty in the projected future trajectory of human demography. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the role of human demography in shaping the future of this important natural disturbance.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of nature. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to a luminescent symbiont in a squid is tightly regulated by the host. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont, and that its catabolism modulates the pH of the symbiont’s habitat, which in turn enhances its luminescence. These findings suggest that the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery may be a general mechanism for regulating the activities of symbionts in their hosts.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding the world. However, the sheer volume of text data makes it difficult to identify latent patterns. We introduce a method to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent patterns in the US National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. This approach can be applied to a wide range of domains, from social media to medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and to understand the gendered nature of these patterns.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe from Asia, and that this introduction occurred only once. However, we show that the bacterium was introduced repeatedly into European harbors, with a delay of 15 y, and that these introductions were not the consequence of a single introduction. Our results suggest that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was the result of a complex interplay between the climate, the trade routes, and the human population. This interplay is likely to have played a role in the establishment of the second plague pandemic in Europe.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases to affect the marine environment. The disease has been observed on all continents and in all oceans, and has resulted in the loss of millions of sea stars. Here, we provide evidence that a virus is the cause of the disease. The virus is transmitted by direct contact and is highly concentrated in the tissues of affected sea stars. The virus has been present in the marine environment for at least 72 y, suggesting that it has been present for a long time before it became a disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. The disease is characterized by the presence of a small population of cells that are responsible for the maintenance of the disease. We have identified a target for antibody-based therapy of AML, which is expressed on these cells. This target is also expressed on a subset of normal hematopoietic stem cells, but not on normal progenitor cells. Hence, the target is a promising therapeutic target for AML, but also for the treatment of normal hematopoiesis. We show that the target is a promising therapeutic target for AML, and that the target can be targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent history of admixture. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the study of human evolution and migration. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with two genes and interferes with their regulation by the protein. These observations demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a mechanism that has evolved to regulate the expression of genes that are important for survival in changing environments.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. This work also provides a framework for the development of deep learning algorithms to optimize the design of other protein molecules.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and manage agricultural production. However, the vast majority of crop experts are not formally surveyed, and the information they provide is often not used to improve crop management. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the primary source of information on crop status, is based on a network of “people as sensors” that provide a continuous, probabilistic assessment of crop status. We show that this network of “people as sensors” is statistically robust and maintains similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate how this network can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of expert knowledge in agriculture. It also provides a new tool for the monitoring of agricultural production and the early detection of anomalies. This work has the potential to improve the efficiency of agricultural production and management.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a new account of memory in language that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We also show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The soil is a major carbon reservoir in the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest. In particular, the release of carbon dioxide from the soil in response to warming is hypothesized to be a major contributor to the overall increase in atmospheric CO2. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Our analysis provides a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. Our results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results also demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. These results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on soil respiration in a broad range of ecosystems.

The transition from autotrophy to parasitism is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because of the difficulty in obtaining information about the ancestral state. Here, we show that the transition to obligate parasitism is linked to a change in the evolutionary rate of plastid genes, which is linked to the loss of photosynthesis. Our results suggest that the transition to parasitism is a stepwise process, in which the evolutionary rate of plastid genes is relaxed in a series of rate equilibria. These equilibria are linked to the modified turnover rates of the proteins in the plastid. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome, which is the most ancient organelle genome. They also have implications for the evolution of the host–parasite relationship.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of climate change impacts. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the creation of the first nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The biosynthesis of the photosynthetic pigments, bacteriochlorophyll and bacteriopheophytin, is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and the identification of three classes of the enzyme.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a mouse model of multiple sclerosis. We found that ASK1 is required for the development of neuroinflammation in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes, and that ASK1 is required for the development of neuroinflammation in microglia, but not astrocytes. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the development of cell-type–specific therapies for multiple sclerosis. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased over the past two decades, and that this increase is likely due to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. This increase in the probability of drought is likely to continue in a warmer world.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes and the causal mechanisms is a major challenge. In this study, we identified the converging functions of autism-risk genes, which are the targets of multiple risk variants, by using a reversal-learning task. We found that the loss of function of five autism-risk genes all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which was indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for the identification of the causal genes and the causal mechanisms of autism. It also provides a method for the identification of the converging functions of autism-risk genes. This study is expected to contribute to the development of a treatment for autism.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 Ca2+ sensor that result in a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities. We also identify mutations in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of hematological abnormalities. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, which is in turn dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and the development of therapeutic strategies to limit the spread of disease. (Show more)

Bats are the only mammals that can survive in caves, and they are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein is a potent immunosuppressant that facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunosuppressant protein. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key regulator of cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that the cancer cell-line screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). This effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapeutic. They also provide a rationale for the use of formate as a metabolic therapeutic in DLBCL. Finally, they provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapeutic.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that affects motor neurons and is caused by a variety of genetic mutations. Here, we show that the proteins that are colocalized with mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and FUS in inclusion bodies are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device can be used to study the physics of the quantum many-body systems, including the quantum phase transitions, the superfluid– Mott insulator transition, and the Bose–Hubbard insulator transition. The device can also be used to study the physics of the quantum many-body systems, including the quantum phase transitions, the superfluid– Mott insulator transition, and the Bose–Hubbard insulator transition.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic and may have been very common at an early stage of evolution. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolution of DNA viruses in particular is poorly understood. Here we present the genomes of ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) from individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique opportunity to study the evolution of humans and viruses over thousands of years. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. These changes are the result of a complex interplay of natural and human factors. In this paper, we show that the observed rate of sea level rise is consistent with the influence of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and it has important implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate with indole, a reaction that is the second step in the mechanism of tryptophan synthase. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction pathway, including the location of the hydrogen atom network, and the role of the cofactor and substrate in the reaction. This work also demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into a reaction that is not observed in the wild-type enzyme. This work is a significant step toward the goal of understanding enzyme mechanisms by combining NMR spectroscopy with crystallography. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a newly identified coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for the development of new therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. The data presented here support the testing of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance in the current context of the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn use the resulting metabolites to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning rhythm is established only after the squid has reached sexual maturity, suggesting that it is a critical factor in the establishment of the symbiosis. Our results suggest that the timing of nutrient provision may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their symbionts.

This paper is about the importance of relationships in schools. It is also about the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. In the United States, students are suspended from school at a rate of one per minute. This paper shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a major impact on students’ behavior. The paper also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a powerful predictor of student behavior. This paper is about the importance of relationships in schools. It is also about the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on pol II transcription. We found that pol II is stalled at the EtdT lesions, and the stalling is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also found that the EtdT lesions can induce multiple transcriptional bypass routes, and the error-free route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route is observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work will help us to understand the etiology of human diseases and

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes pneumonia in humans. To understand the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus-surface spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may inform the development of therapeutic strategies to combat this disease.

The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food system also has the potential to contribute to population health, but the food system is also a major contributor to obesity. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60% and decrease the proportion of meat meals purchased by 15%. This is a large contribution to the global environmental and population health challenges. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering operations is a simple and effective way to contribute to more sustainable diets and population health.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six isogenic breast epithelial cell lines expressing different oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer. It also provides a platform for future studies of the cell surface proteome in other types of cancer and in normal development. This work is a major step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer.

The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. In this paper, we provide evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2020 election. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response, and it is hypothesized that accessory proteins such as ORF8 contribute to this evasion. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. We also show that this protein can form a large-scale dimeric structure, which is not possible for SARS-CoV. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which ORF8 contributes to the severe disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful for the treatment of cerebral edema. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we address the challenge of “selective inference.” This is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations that we find in data. We show how to do this in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this paper will help scientists to better understand the strengths and limitations of the tools that they use in their work.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a direct inducer of vascular ECs. ETV2 is a key regulator of vascular EC development, and its expression is required for the formation of mature vascular networks in vivo. Our study provides a better understanding of the development of vascular ECs and will be useful for the generation of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of photoreceptor that is present in the eyes and skin of adult zebrafish. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and LTK and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a foundation for future studies on the role of these ligands in human diseases.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple causes and mechanisms. In this study, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of diabetic mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the role of STING in T2D and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The packaging of their genome is a key step in their replication, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism is suspected. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We showed that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also showed that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A virus. It also provides a framework for the development of new strategies to control influenza A virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in increasing the fire niche and the need to reduce the risk of wildfire.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic well-being of the residents of those neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It also demonstrates the arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne arbovirus that has been linked to microcephaly and other neurological disorders in newborns of infected mothers. The mechanisms of ZIKV pathogenesis are not fully understood, but the virus is known to replicate within cells. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We find that the virus replicates rapidly and that the time to detectable virus in the blood is short. We also find that the antiviral treatment favipiravir, which blocks viral replication, can reduce the time to undetectable virus in the blood. However, the treatment is most effective when given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. The results presented here can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. Coral reefs are the most biodiverse marine ecosystems, but they are also among the most threatened ecosystems on the planet. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is the most severe threat to coral reefs today. We show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, ultimately leading to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the context of cancer, the intestinal epithelium is transformed into a tumor, which can lead to the loss of the epithelial barrier and the dysregulation of the microbiome. Here, we show that the microbiome can influence the growth of intestinal tumors and that the loss of the epithelial barrier can lead to a dysregulation of the microbiome. We also show that the microbiome can influence the activity of the tumor, and that the loss of the epithelial barrier can lead to a dysregulation of the microbiome. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the tumor microenvironment to maintain the integrity of the epithelial barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. This work also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in cancer progression.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression correlates with the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize and re-engrave Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can inhibit the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize and re-engrave Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key piece of the climate puzzle, but the cause of this event is still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation, with the eruptions’ timing and location exactly matching the start of deglaciation, provide a unique opportunity to test the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the timing of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce in many regions of the world. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human and environmental stress. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the world’s poor, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition are scarce. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are a critical source of food, and where conservation efforts should focus to protect both biodiversity and food security. Our results highlight the need to improve the management of freshwater fisheries, which are often neglected in conservation and policy efforts.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the canonical DLK-1/DLK pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is regulated by cAMP signaling. We also show that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in regeneration.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of the genome and the organism. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, which is a major lineage of seed plants. We find that recombination is concentrated in regions of the genome, and that these regions are similar to those in other eukaryotes. This suggests that the distribution of recombination in plants is a conserved feature of eukaryotic evolution.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The resting state network (RSN) topography, as revealed by functional MRI, is a small fraction of the total neuronal activity. We used metabolic PET to identify and validate the RSN topography in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. PD patients showed reduced deactivation of the dominant RSN during rest and during task performance. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct link between the resting organization of the brain and its functional properties. They also suggest that the metabolic RSN topography may be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis and monitoring of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and stability of the mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also required for the stability of the 5′ untranslated region (UTR), which is the part of the mRNA that is transcribed. The 5′ cap structure is also required for the stability of the mitochondrial 5′ UTR, which is the part of the mRNA that is transcribed. We show that the 5′ cap structure is also found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon of prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and is characterized by the absence of estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2. Despite the availability of targeted therapies, the prognosis of TNBC remains poor. In this study, we show that the expression of a cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in TNBC. We also show that FSIP1 is involved in the drug sensitivity of TNBC cells and may, therefore, aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disease that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the altered gut barrier. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the discovery of a pathway for the biosynthesis of these compounds, which is distinct from the known pathways for the biosynthesis of other tomato volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato volatiles and the potential for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because the impacts of climate change are expected to be most severe at the local scale, where biodiversity is often highest. Our results suggest that biodiversity loss will have additional negative impacts on ecosystem functioning, and hence on the services they provide, if species are unable to adapt to the additional stress of warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are thought to form a map of the local environment. However, the organization of these neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main neurons forming the map, are anatomically distinct from other neurons, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC map and will be useful for understanding the function of this important brain structure. This article is protected by copyright. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. In this study, we show that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro–striato–nigral loop form a specialized system that is disrupted in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. This system is composed of striatonigral fibers that originate in striosomes, a region of the substantia nigra pars reticulata, and target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These dendrites and cell bodies, in turn, project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the way we read minds is by looking at the speed at which they respond to us.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and that its deletion in mice results in a reduction in the content of Ca2+ stores in these cells. This, in turn, leads to a reduction in the content of Ca2+ in the SAN, and to a reduction in heart rate. These results reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in Ca2+ stores and SAN function.
