Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si can enhance the resistance of rice to the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by promoting the accumulation of Si in rice leaves and by increasing the activity of the rice leaffolder-induced defense responses. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect plants from insect herbivores. Our findings also suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense responses. This interaction may be important for understanding the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The lipidome is also affected by drugs and environmental factors. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor of nitric oxide synthesis, is also involved in ether lipid metabolism and that modulation of tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis affects the lipidome of macrophages. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages and that it is involved in the regulation of the immune response.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a new account of memory in language that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We also show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNAs to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment locus of the DNA nanostructure determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the field of plant biology.

The world’s largest lakes are also the most vulnerable to nutrient pollution, which can fuel harmful algal blooms and other ecological and economic impacts. We show that the nutrient inputs to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, are driven by small streams that drain the surrounding landscape. These findings have implications for the management of nutrient pollution in large lakes worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a network of chemical reactions in a thermodynamic environment. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which are believed to be caused by disruption of the receptor. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity, and that this can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs, and may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis. This work also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system history. However, the history of abrupt climate change is difficult to reconstruct because of the long time scales involved. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was accompanied by a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. Here, we show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33%. Nevertheless, most plantations were already deforested by 2015, and certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the need for certification to be tightly linked to the conservation and climate goals of the companies that purchase certified palm oil.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and its function in both plant and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In other vertebrates, sex is determined by multiple loci, resulting in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we show that the multiple sex determination alleles in a single species can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in the evolution of varied secondary sexual characteristics. This modular interplay of sex determination alleles is a general feature of polygenic sex determination, and provides a context for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating products of photooxidation. We sought to understand how the levels of iron, a key redox metal, impacts the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that iron levels, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, were reduced in mice treated with the iron chelator deferiprone. In addition, iron-deficient mice exhibited reduced levels of the bisretinoid A2E, which was increased in iron-sufficient mice. These findings indicate that iron levels impact the levels of reactive oxygen species-generating products of photooxidation and the levels of bisretinoids. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that iron-deficient mice exhibited reduced light-dependent oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings have implications for understanding the role of iron in the retina and for the development of therapeutic strategies for retinal diseases. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also common. We show that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the prey itself, and that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the predator. These findings help us understand the evolution of predator specialization, and how it has shaped the current food web structure.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution. However, the origin of the distinctive human hand morphology is poorly understood because of the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present in a fossil from 1.42 Mya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive human hand morphology arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key regulator of cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer cell growth, and that this effect is rooted in reduced cell growth in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a metabolic pathway that can be targeted to block cancer cell growth, and we have identified a metabolic pathway that can be targeted to block lymphoma growth. These findings have the potential to impact cancer therapy.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and, in turn, their health and well-being.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% over the last 60 y. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
